Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Precise Ethylene Copolymers and Ionomers Using Dielectric Spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project will explore the fundamental dynamics of a new class of polymer system: copolymers with monodisperse ethylene sequences between very precisely spaced acid (or ionic) functionalities. Motivated by the recent synthesis and self-assembly of poly(ethylene-acrylic acid) [PEAA] precise copolymers and ionomers this study will focus on the comprehensive investigation of polymer and ion dynamics of these novel materials using primarily broadband dielectric spectroscopy. Recent findings demonstrate that these materials exhibit considerably less heterogeneity than traditional ethylene-based copolymers with randomly placed functionality. Significantly narrower dielectric relaxations are anticipated, making these ideal model materials for the fundamental study of polymer dynamics.

The role that highly regular self-assembly of ionic domains has on ion transport will be investigated in order to determine whether precise ethylene ionomers offer a unique route to mechanically robust, yet highly conductive, solid polymer membranes. As there is an intimate connection between phase-separated microstructure and molecular dynamics, a thorough understanding of the nanoscale structure of the precise ethylene copolymers and ionomers is required. Consequently, an important component of this project involves collaborations with other institutions on morphological and moedling aspects of these new materials.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project focuses on the systematic investigation of polymer and ion motions in a new class of molecularly precise polymeric materials. The study will also enhance the basic understanding of ion transport in solid polymers, of interest for the next generation of membranes for lithium ion batteries, actuators, and other potential applications. Ethylene-based polymers are of strategic industrial importance, representing the largest class of commercial polymers. As this project is the first to investigate polymer and ion motions of precise ethylene-based acid copolymers and ionomers, it will assist in evaluating the commercial potential of these new materials.

The project will create learning opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, the latter participating through senior thesis projects or as part of the NSF-REU Program at Penn State on soft materials. Program participants will engage in outreach activities, particularly those connected with Penn State's Women in Science and Engineering Institute.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the experimental investigation of molecular motions in a new class of polymeric materials. The new materials under study have acid or ionic pendent groups precisely attached to polyethylene chains at exact intervals, and the acid/ionic pendent groups microphase separate from the polyethylene portion and form a variety of interesting morphologies. The principal experimental method used in this investigation was dielectric spectroscopy, a powerful tool for investigating molecular motions and dynamics of materials. In brief, the experimental findings demonstrated that acid/ion pendent group type and concentration play a critical role in determining local and segmental polymer motions, which are important in controlling the ultimate physical properties of these novel materials. 


Ethylene-based polymers are of strategic industrial importance, representing the largest and arguably the most important class of commercial polymers. As this project was the first to investigate polymer and ion motions in these molecularly precise ionic polymers, it will assist in evaluating the commercial potential of these materials. The investigation also provided insight into ion transport in these solid polymers, of interest for next generation actuators and membranes for lithium ion batteries. 


This project created learning opportunities for a number of graduate and undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral fellows. Three graduate students were partially supported on this grant: one received her Ph.D. during the first program year, while the others are expected to defend Ph.D. dissertations in summer 2015. Three post-doctoral fellows were also supported in part by this grant. Three out of the six people directly supported during the course of this grant are women. Four undergraduate students participated in laboratory research experiences directly related to this grant. Two participated through support from the Penn State Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) program and two through support of the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at Penn State on Soft Materials. The goal of the WISER program is to provide mentoring and learning experiences that most closely duplicate how science and engineering are conducted professionally.

Modified by: James P Runt

Image
  • Left: Chemical structure of a representative polyethylene-based precise ionomer containing ionic liquid pendent groups on every 15th carbon atom (p15ImBr). Right: Dielectric loss spectrum of the p15ImBr ionomer. The transition labeled as 'alpha' is associated with polymer segmental motion.

Ethylene-based polymers are of strategic industrial importance, representing the largest and arguably the most important class of commercial polymers.
